corpus_questions.question: What imaging technique was used to investigate the formation of crystal-like structures in the rabbit kidney, and how does it help in understanding drug-related physiological changes?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: DESI-MS imaging was used to investigate the formation of crystal-like structures in the rabbit kidney. This technique helps in understanding drug-related physiological changes by providing a useful tool in drug development and preclinical trials, specifically by revealing the composition of these structures, which could be composed of the investigational drug candidate, its metabolites, or an endogenous compound deposited as a reaction to the drug administration.

Measurements in the time-resolved mode further complicate
data analysis and interpretation. In this case, additional temporal
dimensionality is introduced, which leads to a collection of large
4D or even 5D dimensional datasets. Though methods discussed in
Secs. III (PCA, NMF, k-means) can be used for dimensionality
reduction, in some cases interpretation of even simplified data can
be challenging. This problem can be resolved by sacrificing some
non-significant dimensionalities.76 In this case, temporal evolution
can be considered as a set of profiles of chemicals’ concertation
across the biased electrodes. Those profiles can be used to further
identify the motion of individual ions.
In another example of time-resolved ToF-SIMS research in
HOIP, the NMF analysis allowed to explore the contribution of
organic degradation products to the overall electrical response of
HOIP-based devices (Fig. 20).78 This analysis allowed to reveal the
presence of a statistically significant component, which demon-
strated hysteretic behavior [Fig. 20(g)]. The analysis of the corre-
sponding endmember (mass spectrum) showed that it is mostly
contributed by methylammonium decomposition products, which
can be, in turn, a cause of observed hysteretic behavior of the
HOIP device.
Summarizing, operando and time-resolved ToF-SIMS modes
are still new and powerful techniques, which can be used to extend
the abilities of local chemical studies in material sciences. Those

corpus_questions.question: How does the MS imaging approach used by Bruinen et al. (2016) differ from the time-resolved ToF-SIMS research discussed in Context 2, and what common goal do they share?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The MS imaging approach used by Bruinen et al. (2016) involves investigating drug-related physiological changes, such as the formation of crystal-like structures in the kidney, while the time-resolved ToF-SIMS research focuses on exploring the contribution of organic degradation products to the overall electrical response of HOIP-based devices. Both approaches aim to provide detailed spatial and temporal information about chemical distributions within tissues or materials.

corpus_questions.question: How does the method of warping the mass dimension without standards (COW calibration) help in analyzing ToF-SIMS data, and what kind of analysis techniques can be applied to the resulting datasets?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: COW calibration helps in analyzing ToF-SIMS data by effectively reducing m/z shifts across the MSI data post-acquisition, enabling the identification and separation of two adjacent peaks and eliminating interference. This method can be used in conjunction with other analysis techniques such as NMF (Non-negative Matrix Factorization), which was used in one example of time-resolved ToF-SIMS research in HOIP to explore the contribution of organic degradation products to the overall electrical response of HOIP-based devices.

by warping the mass dimension without standards. In this ap-
proach, each mass spectrum is recalibrated by maximizing its
similarity to the reference spectrum as shown in Figure 3A.
The similarity of two centroid spectra is obtained by modeling
each peak as a Gaussian function and calculating the sum of
all pairwise peak overlaps (Figure 3B). In addition to m/z loca-
tion, height, and peak width, the spatial information has been
also utilized to further improve the quality of mass alignment.
This approach eﬀectively reduces m/z shifts across the MSI data
postacquisition. In Figure 3C, peak m/z values extracted from
the entire MSI data set before and after spectral alignment are
shown in cyan and orange colors, respectively. COW calibration
enables the identiﬁcation and separation of two adjacent peaks
eliminating the interference shown in Figure 3D. Using a nar-
row mass window, recalibrated MSI data generate two ion images
of these features with distinct spatial distributions (Figure 3E,F).
In another approach, signals of known background ions and en-
dogenous lipids observed in MSI experiments have been used as
calibrants.[45,46] For example, Rocca et al.[46] developed a method
by mining m/z values of endogenous calibrants from publicly
available MSI data repository. By searching a large number of
datasets, they generated an m/z list for candidate endogenous bi-
ological signals. Then, they calculated and selected matches be-

corpus_questions.question: What transformation technique is used to recalibrate mass spectra, and how does it relate to the concept of dilation and erosion in image processing?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The transformation technique used to recalibrate mass spectra is called COW calibration, which involves warping the mass dimension without standards by maximizing the similarity to a reference spectrum. This is analogous to the concept of dilation and erosion in image processing, where dilation and erosion are increasing translation invariant operators that modify the shape of objects in an image.

Animals
The male adult Wistar rats weighing 180 to 200 g were
obtained from Vital River Laboratory Animal Technology Co.
Ltd. (Beijing, China). The rats were kept at a constant room
temperature of 20 ± 1 °C under a scheduled 12 h light:12 h
dark cycle and allowed ad libitum access to food and water.
The rats were randomly assigned to two groups. The rats in the
control group (n = 6) were fed with a normal pellet diet, while
the rats in the diabetes model group (n = 10) were fed with a
high-fat diet. Four weeks later, the diabetes model rats were
given intraperitoneally (i.p.) STZ at a dose of 35 mg/kg,
whereas the control rats were injected i.p. with vehicle citrate
buﬀer (pH 4.4). Fasting blood glucose (FBG) concentrations
were determined 5−7 days after the STZ or vehicle
administration. Diabetic rats were diagnosed if the FBG levels
exceed 16.7 mmol/L for 3 consecutive days and chosen for
further pathological studies (n = 6). After 12 weeks of
observation, Morris water maze (MWM) experiments were
performed to determine the spatial learning and memory
abilities of the rats. Finally, blood samples were harvested for
biological analysis, and the brains samples were collected and
snap-frozen. All samples were kept at −80 °C before the
analysis. The animal experiments for this study were performed
following the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory
Animals and were approved by the animal welfare ethics
committee of Beijing Union-Genius Pharmaceutical Technol-

corpus_questions.question: What technique is used for recalibrating mass spectra to improve m/z alignment, and how does it impact the identification of adjacent peaks in diabetic rat tissue samples?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: COW calibration is used for recalibrating mass spectra to improve m/z alignment. This technique helps in identifying and separating two adjacent peaks, which is particularly useful in analyzing tissue samples from diabetic rats.

corpus_questions.question: What type of diet was used to create the diabetes model group in the animal study, and what method might be used to normalize the biological data obtained from such experiments?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The diabetes model group in the animal study was fed a high-fat diet. For normalizing the biological data obtained from such experiments, methods like those described in the literature, such as the Normalyzerde online tool for improved normalization of omics expression data and high-sensitivity differential expression analysis, could be utilized.
contexts:
USA).
Animals
The male adult Wistar rats weighing 180 to 200 g were
obtained from Vital River Laboratory Animal Technology Co.
Ltd. (Beijing, China). The rats were kept at a constant room
temperature of 20 ± 1 °C under a scheduled 12 h light:12 h
dark cycle and allowed ad libitum access to food and water.
The rats were randomly assigned to two groups. The rats in the
control group (n = 6) were fed with a normal pellet diet, while
the rats in the diabetes model group (n = 10) were fed with a
high-fat diet. Four weeks later, the diabetes model rats were
given intraperitoneally (i.p.) STZ at a dose of 35 mg/kg,
whereas the control rats were injected i.p. with vehicle citrate
buﬀer (pH 4.4). Fasting blood glucose (FBG) concentrations
were determined 5−7 days after the STZ or vehicle
administration. Diabetic rats were diagnosed if the FBG levels
exceed 16.7 mmol/L for 3 consecutive days and chosen for
further pathological studies (n = 6). After 12 weeks of
observation, Morris water maze (MWM) experiments were
performed to determine the spatial learning and memory
abilities of the rats. Finally, blood samples were harvested for
biological analysis, and the brains samples were collected and
snap-frozen. All samples were kept at −80 °C before the
analysis. The animal experiments for this study were performed
following the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory
Animals and were approved by the animal welfare ethics
committee of Beijing Union-Genius Pharmaceutical Technol-

Background
Why study ‘cells’ with ‘‑omic’ detail?
As an early pioneer of the microscope, Robert Hooke 
coined the term ‘cell’ in the 1600s to describe struc-
tures observed under magnification in plant material; 
~ 400 years later, the word and the concept has stuck, 
achieving primacy as a fundamental unit of life on Earth. 
Unicellular organisms epitomize how cells are governed 
by their nucleic acids, by their DNA, which houses ‘genes’ 
that encode proteins, and messenger RNAs (mRNA), 
which act as an intermediary between the two. This is 
also true for multi-cellular life, including human beings. 
Indeed, our understanding of ‘cell theory’ underpins 
almost every aspect of human health and disease, from 
islet cells in the pancreas protecting against diabetes, 
immune cells making protective antibodies against bacte-
ria and viruses, or neuronal cells storing life experiences 
and memories. A comprehensive understanding of how 
individual cells employ their mRNA and proteins in dif-
ferent tissues of the human body may lead to new strate-

corpus_questions.question: What are some methods used for analyzing biological data in mass spectrometry, and how do these methods relate to the normalization techniques discussed in the J. Proteome Res. articles?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: Mass spectrometry data can be analyzed using various methods such as desorption electrospray ionization, secondary ion MS, and infrared matrix-assisted laser desorption electrospray ionization. These methods are often used in conjunction with normalization techniques like those described in the J. Proteome Res. articles, which focus on improving the normalization of omics expression data and conducting high-sensitivity differential expression analysis.

model deviate from the values used to generate the data while the correctly speciﬁed
model yield similar variance estimates which are close to the true ones. The RMSEs
and biases are smaller in the correctly speciﬁed models. As the sample size increases
from 20 × 20 to 50 × 50, the estimated values become closer to the true values.
Similarly, in Table 5, the ﬁxed effects estimates are close to the true values and are
more accurate in the correct model than the under-speciﬁed model. For the random
effects, the under-speciﬁed models yield the variance estimates that deviate from
the true values, but they are similar in the correct model. These results are supported
by smaller RMSEs and biases for the correctly speciﬁed model, with no discernible
pattern in the biases. Comparing Tables 4 and 5, we ﬁnd that as the model become
more complex (from two to four slopes), the bias and the RMSEs for random effects

corpus_questions.question: What methods were used for data analysis and how did they ensure the accuracy of fixed and random effects estimates in the study?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The study utilized various analytical methods such as Bayesian estimates, 95% credible intervals, scale reduction factor (R̂), root mean squared error (RMSE), and bias for 20 replications. This ensured the accuracy of fixed effects estimates by making them similar to the values used to simulate the data, while the random effects estimates in the correctly specified model yielded variance estimates close to the true ones, as indicated by the R̂ values being less than 1.20, suggesting convergence.

of users (e.g., on the basis of race, gender, and age) is reported
and documented transparently. These model cards complement
the datasheets introduced by Gebru et al.69 to document details
about datasets in a standard format.
The use of checklists has also been impactful in improving re-
porting practices in the few ﬁelds that have adopted them.70
Although checklists and model cards provide concrete best
practices for reporting standards,38–40,71 current efforts do not
address pitfalls arising because of leakage. Further, even though
several scientiﬁc ﬁelds, especially those related to medicine,
have adopted checklists to improve reporting standards, most
checklists are developed for speciﬁc scientiﬁc or research com-
munities instead of ML-based science in general.
Scientiﬁc arguments to surface and prevent leakage
When ML models are used to make scientiﬁc claims, it is not
enough to simply separate the training and test sets and report
performance metrics on the test set. Unlike research in ML
methods, where a model’s performance on a hypothetical task
(i.e., one that is not linked to a speciﬁc scientiﬁc claim) is still of
interest to the researcher in some cases,72 in ML-based science,
claims about a model’s performance need to be connected to
scientiﬁc claims using explicit arguments. The burden of proof
for ensuring the correctness of these arguments is on the
researcher making the scientiﬁc claims.73

Hence the image after dilation will be brighter or increased 
in intensity. It also expands the image and mainly used to 
fill the spaces. Erosion is just opposite to dilation. It is 
defined as the minimum value in the window .The image 
after dilation will be darker than the original image. It 
shrinks or thins the image. Opening and closing both 
parameters are formed by using dilation and erosion. In 
opening, firstly image will be eroded and then it will be 
followed by dilation. In closing, the first step will be dilated 
and then result of this is followed by erosion [4]. 
A. Dilation Operation 
  Dilation operation is one of the bases of morphology 
processing. Dilation is the operation of “lengthening” or 
“thickening” in binary image. This special way and the 
extent of thickening are controlled by structural elements. 
Mathematically, dilation is defined as set operation. A is 
dilated by B, written as AB, is defined as [1]

corpus_questions.question: What are the differences between dilation and erosion operations in image processing, and how do these operations relate to the documentation and reporting practices discussed in the context of ML models?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: In image processing, dilation increases the intensity and expands the image by filling in the gaps, while erosion decreases the intensity and shrinks the image by removing pixels on object boundaries. These operations are fundamental in morphological processing. In contrast, the contexts discuss the importance of documenting and reporting practices in ML models, such as using model cards and checklists to ensure transparency and address issues like data leakage. While these practices help in making robust scientific claims with ML models, they do not directly involve image processing operations like dilation and erosion.

parameters are formed by using dilation and erosion. In 
opening, firstly image will be eroded and then it will be 
followed by dilation. In closing, the first step will be dilated 
and then result of this is followed by erosion [4].

extent of thickening are controlled by structural elements.

corpus_questions.question: What are the effects of dilation and erosion operations on an image, and how do these operations relate to the merging of microbial sequences onto a 3D MSI map?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: Dilation increases the brightness and expands the image, while erosion decreases the brightness and shrinks the image. These operations are fundamental in morphological processing and can be combined to form opening and closing operations. In contrast, the merging of microbial 16S rRNA amplicon sequences onto a 3D MSI map involves complex bioinformatics and spatial analysis techniques, which are distinct from image processing operations like dilation and erosion.

Resolutions on registration accuracy. This optimization analysis was conducted for Affine registration; however, 
Euler and Similarity registration exhibited similar trends. As shown in Figs. 7 and 8, the Mutual Information 
and Dice coefficient are highest, and the Hausdorff Distance value is lowest for a Number of Bins equal to 64 and 
a Number of Resolutions equal to 7. These parameter values provided the highest accuracy and were therefore 
selected for the intensity-based image registration between different modality pairs. Following this optimization, 
we compared our proposed model with the optimized intensity registration model to assess relative performance.
Image registration for ANHIR grand challenge datasets
We performed image registration on the ANHIR Grand Challenge datasets using elastic models with three 
transformation approaches: Euler, Similarity, and Affine. Using optimized parameters from our previous analysis, 
we evaluated the registration accuracy across different tissue samples. Figure 9 demonstrate the registration 
results for representative cases, while additional examples are provided in the supplementary materials.
Figure 9, along with the figures in the supplementary file, illustrate the results of the image registration 
experiments using Euler, similarity, and affine transformations within the elastic model framework. All three 
approaches provided good results, successfully aligning the images with high accuracy across the majority of

corpus_questions.question: What parameter settings were found to provide the highest accuracy in image registration, and how might these settings be relevant to preparing samples for mass spectrometry imaging?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The parameter settings that provided the highest accuracy in image registration were a Number of Bins equal to 64 and a Number of Resolutions equal to 7. These settings could be relevant to preparing samples for mass spectrometry imaging as they optimize the accuracy of registration, which is crucial for aligning different modalities in imaging experiments. Similarly, in mass spectrometry imaging, careful preparation steps such as washing the sample with ethanol and allowing it to dry in a vacuum desiccator ensure that the sample is properly prepared for the deposition of matrix solution, which is essential for accurate signal detection.

corpus_questions.ground_truth: The optimization parameters selected for image registration were a Number of Bins equal to 64 and a Number of Resolutions equal to 7, as these provided the highest accuracy for Mutual Information and Dice coefficient and the lowest Hausdorff Distance. In contrast, the Fast articulated motion tracking paper discusses various methods such as sums of Gaussians body model and direct voxel grid optimization, focusing on super-fast convergence for radiance fields reconstruction.

collisional cooling, which can prevent the fragmentation of ions
with high internal energy or labile chemical moieties and thus
lead to higher intact ion signals.85,86 Furthermore, EP preserves
a dense and reactive MALDI plume for the first few
microseconds after laser irradiation allowing for more gas
phase collisions and enhanced ionization.89 Another practical
advantage is that EP sources can be easily coupled to ion
mobility spectrometers, which operate at a similar pressure.87
Alternatively, MALDI can also be performed at atmospheric
pressure (AP). AP MALDI enables the analysis of hydrated
samples containing small, volatile molecules, which cannot be
detected with EP- or HV MALDI. Moreover, it allows using
volatile matrices, which enables longer imaging runs and in
some cases can yield enhanced ion signals.90 The main
disadvantage of AP MALDI is its reduced sensitivity compared
to EP- and HV MALDI due to an increased rate of ion
losses.91,92 The inlet of AP- MALDI mass spectrometers
usually is heated to 200-550 °C to improve sensitivity.92,93
Another improvement has been the coupling of AP MALDI to
MALDI-2 and dielectric barrier discharge ionization (DBDI),
which lead to an increase in ion yield for many molecules,
especially at lower masses,92 and, similarly to MALDI-2 at EP,
allowed imaging molecules which previously were not
detectable with AP MALDI.92−94 However, DBDI also made
several ion signals vanish,92 and caused increased in-source

corpus_questions.question: What are the advantages and disadvantages of using atmospheric pressure matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (AP MALDI) compared to enhanced pulsed (EP) or high-voltage (HV) MALDI, and how might these differences impact the analysis of oral cancer samples using mass spectrometry?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: AP MALDI allows the analysis of hydrated samples containing small, volatile molecules and uses volatile matrices, which can enable longer imaging runs and potentially enhanced ion signals. However, it has reduced sensitivity compared to EP- and HV MALDI due to an increased rate of ion losses. In contrast, EP MALDI preserves a dense and reactive MALDI plume for the first few microseconds after laser irradiation, allowing for more gas phase collisions and enhanced ionization, but it may not be suitable for analyzing hydrated samples or small, volatile molecules as effectively as AP MALDI.

Globally, the incidence rate of oral cancer is 3.9 per 100 000
people when adjusted for age.20 Alcohol consumption, tobacco
use, and the rising incidence of oropharyngeal cancer (more
specically, tonsil and base of tongue cancer) linked to human
papillomavirus (HPV) infection are all common risk factors for
developing oral cancer.20 Patients with oral cancer are typically
identied when their invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
has reached an advanced stage.21 Roughly half of patients
survive ve years aer initial disease diagnosis because of
delayed
disease
presentation
and
a
lack
of
appropriate
screening techniques to detect early oral cancer.22 Despite
improvements in radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and surgery, the
mortality rate from oral cancer at ve years has not changed
drastically in more than 50 years.21 Local recurrence of the
patient's primary tumor is the most frequent reason for treat-
ment failure and death in oral cancer patients.23 Oral cancer can
be found in the oral cavity, where the oral surface epithelium
can be easily examined visually and physically. A denitive
determination of the presence of cancer or precancerous lesions
does not appear to be possible with the current methods for oral
cavity cancer screening.24 Currently, a biopsy and pathological
examination of the removed tissue serve as the only reliable
methods of detection.25,26 However, even in this situation, the

corpus_questions.question: What are the advantages and disadvantages of Atmospheric Pressure (AP) Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization (MALDI) compared to Enhanced Pressure (EP) and High Voltage (HV) MALDI, and how might these differences impact the analysis of certain types of samples?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The main advantage of AP MALDI is its ability to analyze hydrated samples containing small, volatile molecules, which cannot be detected with EP- or HV MALDI, and it allows using volatile matrices, which can enable longer imaging runs and potentially enhance ion signals. However, it has a reduced sensitivity compared to EP- and HV MALDI due to an increased rate of ion losses. In contrast, EP preserves a dense and reactive MALDI plume for the first few microseconds after laser irradiation, allowing for more gas phase collisions and enhanced ionization, and can be easily coupled to ion mobility spectrometers operating at a similar pressure.

ments with incompatible sample preparations [7]. This way the authors 
could combine the data obtained in five different experiments on a per 
pixel level from proteins, dual polarity phospholipids, cholesterol, free 
fatty acids, and triglycerides. While this allowed finding spatially 
correlated ions across the different molecular classes, the integration of 
these datasets for multivariate algorithms requires new normalisation 
strategies to guarantee equal contributions. 
3D-MSI 
Aligning MSI datasets spatially to each other is also necessary in 
cross-section based three-dimensional (3D) MSI. This is mainly 
encountered in MALDI and DESI-MSI where serial sections of the sample 
are used to obtain a volumetric representation of the sample [40]. While 
the alignment of a stack of 2D images to a 3D volume shares similarities 
to the previous approaches, the overall aim is to reconstruct the original 
3D volume as close to the original in vivo sample as possible. 
To achieve this, several workflows have been developed over the last 
16 years, which primarily differ in the actual images that are used to 
align the stack of 2D images to a 3D volume (Fig. 5A). The first section- 
based 3D-MSI study was conducted in 2005 by Crecelius et al., who were 
interested in the 3D visualisation of protein signals in mouse brain [41]. 
Since the authors found that “the cumulative error produced by aligning 
successive ion images to be greater than that produced by aligning each

corpus_questions.question: What are the challenges in integrating mass spectrometry imaging (MSI) datasets for multivariate analysis, and how might these challenges relate to the limitations in improving survival rates for oral cancer patients?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: Challenges in integrating MSI datasets for multivariate analysis include the need for new normalization strategies to ensure equal contributions from different molecular classes, as mentioned in Context 2. Similarly, the limitations in improving survival rates for oral cancer patients, as described in Context 1, highlight the importance of early detection and appropriate screening techniques, which are hindered by delayed disease presentation.
contexts:
Globally, the incidence rate of oral cancer is 3.9 per 100 000
people when adjusted for age.20 Alcohol consumption, tobacco
use, and the rising incidence of oropharyngeal cancer (more
specically, tonsil and base of tongue cancer) linked to human
papillomavirus (HPV) infection are all common risk factors for
developing oral cancer.20 Patients with oral cancer are typically
identied when their invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
has reached an advanced stage.21 Roughly half of patients
survive ve years aer initial disease diagnosis because of
delayed
disease
presentation
and
a
lack
of
appropriate
screening techniques to detect early oral cancer.22 Despite
improvements in radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and surgery, the
mortality rate from oral cancer at ve years has not changed
drastically in more than 50 years.21 Local recurrence of the
patient's primary tumor is the most frequent reason for treat-
ment failure and death in oral cancer patients.23 Oral cancer can
be found in the oral cavity, where the oral surface epithelium
can be easily examined visually and physically. A denitive
determination of the presence of cancer or precancerous lesions
does not appear to be possible with the current methods for oral
cavity cancer screening.24 Currently, a biopsy and pathological
examination of the removed tissue serve as the only reliable
methods of detection.25,26 However, even in this situation, the
pathologist's evaluation is still inherently subjective despite

ments with incompatible sample preparations [7]. This way the authors 
could combine the data obtained in five different experiments on a per 
pixel level from proteins, dual polarity phospholipids, cholesterol, free 
fatty acids, and triglycerides. While this allowed finding spatially 
correlated ions across the different molecular classes, the integration of 
these datasets for multivariate algorithms requires new normalisation 
strategies to guarantee equal contributions. 
3D-MSI 
Aligning MSI datasets spatially to each other is also necessary in 
cross-section based three-dimensional (3D) MSI. This is mainly 
encountered in MALDI and DESI-MSI where serial sections of the sample 
are used to obtain a volumetric representation of the sample [40]. While 
the alignment of a stack of 2D images to a 3D volume shares similarities 
to the previous approaches, the overall aim is to reconstruct the original 
3D volume as close to the original in vivo sample as possible. 
To achieve this, several workflows have been developed over the last 
16 years, which primarily differ in the actual images that are used to 
align the stack of 2D images to a 3D volume (Fig. 5A). The first section- 
based 3D-MSI study was conducted in 2005 by Crecelius et al., who were 
interested in the 3D visualisation of protein signals in mouse brain [41]. 
Since the authors found that “the cumulative error produced by aligning 
successive ion images to be greater than that produced by aligning each

cases (Mutual Information: 1.06 vs. 1.04 for COAD_05), our feature extraction method offered comparable 
results with notable advantages in computational efficiency, completing registrations in approximately half the 
time. These findings demonstrate that our feature-based approach provides a robust alternative to traditional 
intensity-based methods for multimodal image registration in biomedical applications, with the choice 
between them potentially depending on specific use case requirements such as computational resources and 
time constraints. Future work could explore introducing the deep learning architecture and combining these 
approaches to leverage their complementary strengths in handling complex multimodal registration scenarios.
The corresponding author is responsible for submitting a competing interests statement on behalf of all 
authors of the paper.
Future studies
Our approach, while currently focused on 2D registration, provides a benchmark that can be adapted and 
extended to 3D datasets in future studies.

will make the code available on our GitHub repository upon acceptance. For any requests regarding the data 
from this study, please contact the corresponding author.

corpus_questions.question: What are the key considerations for aligning MSI datasets in 3D volumes, and how might a feature-based approach improve upon traditional intensity-based methods for this task?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: Aligning MSI datasets in 3D volumes involves spatially aligning cross-sections of the sample to reconstruct the original 3D volume as closely as possible to the original in vivo sample. A feature-based approach, as mentioned in Context 2, offers comparable results to traditional intensity-based methods for multimodal image registration in biomedical applications but with the advantage of computational efficiency, completing registrations in approximately half the time.

Data Sets for Benchmarking
IonStar. To evaluate the performance of DEA, we use the
IonStar benchmark data set,33 available from the Proteomics
Identifications Database (PRIDE) identifier PXD003881.
DH5α Escherichia coli lysate was spiked in human pancreatic
cancer cells (Panc-1) lysate at five levels: 3%, 4.5%, 6%, 7.5%,
and 9% E. coli. We annotated these dilutions from smallest to
largest with the letters a−e. By comparing the various dilutions,
we obtain different effect sizes; e.g., when comparing dilution e
(9%) against dilution d (7.5%), the expected difference is 1.2 for
E. coli proteins and 1 for human proteins. There are four
technical replicates for each dilution, hence 20 raw files in total.
To compare the performance of the various methods
implemented in prolfqua, we use only the contrasts resulting
in minor differences Δ = (1.20, 1.25, 1.30, 1.50), because for
bigger differences, all models perform similarly.

IonStar data set using MaxQuant8 Version 1.6.10.43, with
MaxQuant default settings for Orbitrap data. The text files

This could be evaluated using a benchmark dataset like IonStar, which is part of the Proteomics Identifications Database (PRIDE) and includes data from protein interaction studies.

corpus_questions.question: What kind of data processing steps are involved in preparing spectral data for analysis, and how might these relate to the implementation of mixed-effect models in evaluating protein interactions?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: Spectral data processing involves baseline correction and peak binning, where common peaks across the set of spectra are selected to serve as calibrants for quadratic calibration. This process can be related to the implementation of mixed-effect models in evaluating protein interactions because both involve handling complex biological data. Mixed-effect models, such as those used in differential expression analysis (DEA), can account for variability within and between groups, which is crucial when analyzing protein interactions with varying sample dilutions.

Table 1: The high-level modular structure of lmer.
1.3. High-level modular structure
The lmer function is composed of four largely independent modules. In the ﬁrst module, a
mixed-model formula is parsed and converted into the inputs required to specify a linear mixed
model (Section 2). The second module uses these inputs to construct an R function which
takes the covariance parameters, θ, as arguments and returns negative twice the log proﬁled
likelihood or the REML criterion (Section 3).
The third module optimizes this objective
function to produce maximum likelihood (ML) or REML estimates of θ (Section 4). Finally,
the fourth module provides utilities for interpreting the optimized model (Section 5).

corpus_questions.question: What is the role of Pericyte cells in tumor angiogenesis, and how does high-resolution 3D reconstruction of blood vessels aid in studying their role and other medical applications?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: Pericyte cells play a significant role in tumor angiogenesis. High-resolution 3D reconstruction of blood vessels is crucial for colocalizing Pericyte cells within the tumor volume, differentiating imaged glands, detecting small lesions and immune cell infiltration, and extracting features such as branching and length of vessels. This aids in more accurate cancer diagnosis.

of immune rejection. It is therefore of great interest to study the role of Pericyte
cells in tumor angiogenesis for which a high-resolution 3D reconstruction of blood
vessels is necessary in order to colocalize the Pericyte cells in the tumor volume. 2)
Reconstruction of the tissue volume can help diﬀerentiate imaged glands that are
cut tangentially during the tissue slicing process from small poorly formed glands,
and therefore helps in more accurate cancer diagnosis. 3) Detection of small lesions
and immune cell inﬁltration will be easier in a high resolution 3D reconstructed
tissue volume. 4) Blood vessel structure can also be used to extract important
features about blood vessels such as branching of vessels, length of vessels, etc.
Considering the high frequency of tissue deformations in the acquired virtual slices
and the large size of these images, previously proposed algorithms are not able
to provide an accurate tissue registration output in a reasonable amount of time.
Also, patch-based ([11, 12, 13]) and vessel-segmentation-based methods ([16, 17]),
discussed earlier, may be misguided by highly deformed regions in the tissue. We
propose a multi-scale approach for registration of the whole slide images for the
region of interest while reducing the eﬀect of such distortions on the registration
results and therefore increasing the accuracy of the registration outcome. In this

corpus_questions.ground_truth: Spatial-DGMM was used to analyze ions with similar spatial distributions in the simulated dataset. This method differs from traditional mass spectrometry techniques, such as those used for analyzing aldehydes in water samples or quantifying neutral and sialylated N-glycans, as it focuses on clustering ions based on their spatial distributions rather than chemical properties.

of every three MR grid points being aligned with CT grid points in both in-plane dimensions.
We can therefore expect interpolation artefacts in the registration function for translations in
the in-plane directions. With partial volume interpolation (third row), we again get a smooth
function for the original resolution and artefact patterns with downsampled images. With
linear interpolation, the registration function of the original images shows slight artefacts.

corpus_questions.question: What technique could be used to reduce artifacts in the registration function when dealing with images of different voxel sizes, and how does it relate to the minimization process in the given mathematical equation?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: To reduce artifacts in the registration function when dealing with images of different voxel sizes, linear interpolation could be used. This relates to the minimization process in the given mathematical equation as the equation involves minimizing the image representation error with respect to the latents, which is similar to the optimization challenge addressed in the ILO algorithm for GAN inversion.

corpus_questions.question: How does the choice of interpolation method during image registration affect the presence of artifacts, and what mathematical concept is used in the optimization process of GAN inversion?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: During image registration, using linear interpolation at the original image resolution results in fewer artifacts compared to partial volume interpolation, especially when dealing with subsampled images. In the optimization process of GAN inversion, the objective function involves minimizing the image representation error with respect to the latents, which is mathematically formulated as a minimization problem involving terms related to the image representation error and regularization.

involves spectral data processing (bottom level), in which molec-
ular features at a pixel level are extracted from the experimental
data for downstream analysis. After preprocessing, MSI data can
be organized as a 3D data cube,[24] which has high dimensionality
in both the spectral and spatial domains. The second level shown
in the middle summarizes data compression by dimensional-
ity reduction and classiﬁcation of either spectral or spatial infor-
mation. This analysis enables spatial segmentation or molecular
colocalization, which links the spectral and spatial information
to provide a concise representation of the vast MSI data. The ﬁ-
nal level of data analysis employs statistical tools to infer biologi-
cal insights from MSI data.[25,26] The statistical analyses are often
coupled with information provided by other imaging modalities,
which places the spatial molecular information into the context
of anatomical regions and/or provides a complementary chem-
ical characterization of the sample.[23] Furthermore, molecular

base-enabled ontology and pathway analysis.

corpus_questions.question: How does the ILO algorithm adaptation for GAN inversion differ from direct solution methods, and how might spectral data processing in MSI be relevant to the interpretation of results obtained from GAN inversion techniques?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The ILO algorithm adaptation for GAN inversion differs from direct solution methods by minimizing the loss with respect to the latents in an intermediate layer and then projecting back to the range space of the previous layers, rather than directly solving the problem with respect to {wt}. Spectral data processing in MSI, which involves extracting molecular features at a pixel level and organizing MSI data into a 3D data cube, can provide relevant information for interpreting the results of GAN inversion techniques, especially in scenarios where tumors efface normal tissue morphology and histopathology is inconclusive.

corpus_questions.question: How does MSI data analysis help in identifying the background parenchyma in glioma diagnosis, and what are the challenges involved in processing such data?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: MSI data analysis helps in identifying the background parenchyma in glioma diagnosis by linking spectral and spatial information to provide a concise representation of the vast MSI data. This is particularly useful when histopathology is inconclusive, as demonstrated in specimen 70 where DESI-MS data could be used to determine the background parenchyma. However, processing such data presents significant challenges due to its high dimensionality and vast amounts of information, requiring effective data reduction techniques to manage the large datasets.

therapeutics [Rubakhin et al., 2005, Vaysse et al., 2017, Kaspar
et al., 2011].
However, the outstanding multiplexing capability of IMS-
capable instruments generates vast amounts of data,
often
containing spatially resolved information for thousands of
molecular species in a single experiment [Caprioli et al., 1997,
Spraggins et al., 2019, Alexandrov, 2012]. The volume and
high-dimensionality of IMS data present significant challenges
in data processing, analysis, and interpretation [Alexandrov,
2012]. One of the primary challenges is data reduction, as
raw IMS datasets typically consist of hundreds of thousands
to millions of spatial locations, i.e., pixels, each associated
with a mass spectrum containing hundreds of thousands of
ion intensities. These datasets contain a mixture of high- and
low-intensity peaks as well as features with varying signal-to-
noise ratios. Managing such large datasets requires effective
data reduction techniques that extract meaningful information

However, the vast amounts of data generated by DESI-MS imaging pose significant challenges in data processing, including data reduction due to the high-dimensionality and large volume of spatially resolved molecular species information.

corpus_questions.question: How can deep learning architectures be applied to improve data reduction techniques in IMS data analysis, and what are the potential drawbacks of using certain architectures?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: Deep learning architectures like encoder-decoder and U-net can be applied to improve data reduction techniques in IMS data analysis by leveraging their ability to extract meaningful information from large and complex datasets. However, adding skip connections to ResNet in U-net can be highly detrimental for the deep image prior, indicating potential drawbacks.

therapeutics [Rubakhin et al., 2005, Vaysse et al., 2017, Kaspar
et al., 2011].
However, the outstanding multiplexing capability of IMS-
capable instruments generates vast amounts of data,
often
containing spatially resolved information for thousands of
molecular species in a single experiment [Caprioli et al., 1997,
Spraggins et al., 2019, Alexandrov, 2012]. The volume and
high-dimensionality of IMS data present significant challenges
in data processing, analysis, and interpretation [Alexandrov,
2012]. One of the primary challenges is data reduction, as
raw IMS datasets typically consist of hundreds of thousands
to millions of spatial locations, i.e., pixels, each associated
with a mass spectrum containing hundreds of thousands of
ion intensities. These datasets contain a mixture of high- and
low-intensity peaks as well as features with varying signal-to-
noise ratios. Managing such large datasets requires effective
data reduction techniques that extract meaningful information

ABSTRACT: Multimodal mass spectrometry imaging (MSI) data presents unique big data challenges in handling and analysis.
Here, we present a pipeline for co-registering matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization MSI and confocal immunoﬂuorescence
imaging data for extracting single-cell metabolite signatures. We further describe methods and introduce software for the
simultaneous analysis of these concatenated data sets, which are designed to establish a connection between cell traits of interest
(shape metrics, position within sample) and the cells’ own metabolic signatures.
KEYWORDS: human induced pluripotent stem cells, multimodal image analysis software, single-cell, metabolomics

corpus_questions.question: How does the proposed co-registration pipeline for multimodal imaging differ from traditional MRI image registration techniques, and what additional features does it include for analyzing stem cell colonies?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The proposed co-registration pipeline for multimodal imaging combines matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization MSI and confocal immuno-fluorescence imaging data to extract single-cell metabolite signatures, linking cell traits such as shape metrics and position within the sample to their metabolic signatures. This differs from traditional MRI image registration techniques, which are typically used for detecting subtle brain changes or registering PET and SPECT images, as it focuses on multimodal data analysis rather than just anatomical alignment.

corpus_questions.question: What techniques are used for co-registering matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization MSI and confocal immunofluorescence imaging data, and how do they relate to other multimodal imaging techniques discussed in the literature?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The co-registration pipeline for matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization MSI and confocal immunofluorescence imaging data involves methods and software designed to establish connections between cell traits and metabolic signatures. This technique relates to other multimodal imaging techniques discussed in the literature, such as subvoxel registration and subtraction of serial MR images, three-dimensional multimodal brain warping using the demons algorithm, and automated interstudy image registration techniques for SPECT and PET.

The ions of proteins or peptides (for MALDI), or of lipids or
metabolites (for DESI and MALDI) are separated according to their
ratios of mass over charge (m/z). This produces a mass spectrum, i.e.
a graph where the x axis represents the m/z of the ions, and the y
axis is the intensity (related to the abundance of the ions). MSI
experiments collect mass spectra in a raster pattern throughout a tis-
sue. A color representation of the intensities of one m/z across the
locations is referred to as an ion image. Mass spectrometric work-
flows differ in their spatial resolution, mass resolution and the dy-
namic range of the intensity signals (Watrous et al., 2011). A typical
experiment contains spectra with tens of thousands of m/z, collected

corpus_questions.question: What techniques are used for image registration in medical imaging, and how do they relate to the process of molecular analysis through DESI-MSI?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: Techniques such as subvoxel registration and subtraction of serial MR images, three-dimensional multimodal brain warping, elastic registration in the presence of intensity variations, and automated interstudy image registration are used for image registration in medical imaging (Context 1). These methods enhance the accuracy of comparing images taken at different times or from different sources. In contrast, DESI-MSI involves generating primary charged droplets from tissue sections for ionization and desorption of molecules (Context 2).

corpus_questions.question: What techniques are used in mass spectrometry imaging (MSI) to separate ions based on their mass-to-charge ratio, and how might these techniques be relevant to understanding the comorbidities associated with osteoarthritis?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: In mass spectrometry imaging (MSI), ions are separated based on their mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) through various techniques such as electrospray ionization and secondary droplet ionization. These techniques are crucial for identifying specific molecules like proteins, peptides, lipids, or metabolites in tissue sections. Understanding MSI can help in comprehending the complex biological processes related to diseases like osteoarthritis, including the identification of biomarkers that may indicate the presence of comorbidities. For instance, a recent systematic review highlighted the importance and frequency of comorbidities experienced by persons with osteoarthritis, suggesting that MSI could provide valuable insights into these conditions.

This criterion uses the shape of peaks to remove false peak
candidates. In order to compute the left slope and the
right slope of a peak, both the left end point and the right
end point of the peak need to be identified. Peak candi-
date is discarded if both left slope and right slope are less
than a threshold. The threshold is defined as half of the
local noise level [14].
P4: Local maximum
A peak is a local maximum of N neighboring points.
P5: Shape ratio
Peak area is computed as the area under the curve within
a small distance of a peak candidate. Shape ratio is com-
puted as the peak area divided by the maximum of all
peak areas. The shape ratio of a peak must be larger than
a threshold.
P6: Ridge lines
Ridge lines are obtained in the following steps:
• Carry out continuous wavelet transform on raw spec-
trum. This step produces 2-D coefficient matrix with size
of M × N, where M is the number of scales and N is the
length of spectrum.
• Connect nearest local maximal coefficients of adjacent
scales to obtain ridge lines. The distance between two
adjacent points on a ridge line should be smaller than a
window size.
• Use a variable gap to count how many successive times
that a local maximal coefficient can not find its nearest
counterpart in the next scale. If the gap is larger than a
given threshold, the ridge line is dropped.

trum. This step produces 2-D coefficient matrix with size
of M × N, where M is the number of scales and N is the
length of spectrum.
• Connect nearest local maximal coefficients of adjacent
scales to obtain ridge lines. The distance between two
adjacent points on a ridge line should be smaller than a
window size.
• Use a variable gap to count how many successive times
that a local maximal coefficient can not find its nearest
counterpart in the next scale. If the gap is larger than a
given threshold, the ridge line is dropped.

This criterion uses the shape of peaks to remove false peak
candidates. In order to compute the left slope and the
right slope of a peak, both the left end point and the right
end point of the peak need to be identified. Peak candi-
date is discarded if both left slope and right slope are less
than a threshold. The threshold is defined as half of the
local noise level [14].
P4: Local maximum
A peak is a local maximum of N neighboring points.
P5: Shape ratio
Peak area is computed as the area under the curve within
a small distance of a peak candidate. Shape ratio is com-
puted as the peak area divided by the maximum of all
peak areas. The shape ratio of a peak must be larger than
a threshold.
P6: Ridge lines
Ridge lines are obtained in the following steps:
• Carry out continuous wavelet transform on raw spec-
trum. This step produces 2-D coefficient matrix with size
of M × N, where M is the number of scales and N is the
length of spectrum.
• Connect nearest local maximal coefficients of adjacent
scales to obtain ridge lines. The distance between two
adjacent points on a ridge line should be smaller than a
window size.
• Use a variable gap to count how many successive times
that a local maximal coefficient can not find its nearest
counterpart in the next scale. If the gap is larger than a
given threshold, the ridge line is dropped.

corpus_questions.question: What is the relationship between the false discovery rate (FOR) controlling procedure and the spatial distribution of cells within a clone, and how might these concepts be applied in the analysis of occupational exposures and knee osteoarthritis?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The false discovery rate (FOR) controlling procedure is a method used to maximize the number of rejections while maintaining a certain level of control over the false discovery rate. This procedure can be seen as a post hoc maximizing procedure that chooses a threshold 'a' to maximize rejections while satisfying a specific constraint. In the context of cell biology, the spatial distribution of cells within a clone can be analyzed using the probability of colocalization, denoted as p(dist(ci, cj) ≤r|i, j ∈Y), which can help identify clone-specific behaviors and stratifications. By comparing these values across different clonal populations, researchers can determine if certain cells tend to stay close or disperse intentionally. These concepts can be applied in the analysis of occupational exposures and knee osteoarthritis by synthesizing data from various studies to understand the risk factors associated with different types of physical activities and occupations, thereby identifying patterns and potential mechanisms related to the development of knee osteoarthritis.

ﬁndings could be directly compared with those of the
previous review.6
Data synthesis
We conducted a best evidence synthesis16 of studies
that examined the association between knee OA and oc-
cupational exposure to (1) heavy lifting, (2) kneeling or
knee bending, (3) combined heavy lifting and kneeling,
and (4) stair climbing. In addition, we examined the risk
of knee OA by occupation and by sex. Finally, we deter-
mined the level of evidence for each type of occupational
exposure (see Appendix 3) based on the design of eligible
studies and their methodological quality as measured by
the Jensen criteria.6 A prospective cohort design was
considered the best design because of its lower risk of
bias and confounders, followed by case-control and cross-
sectional designs.
RESULTS
Identiﬁcation of literature and study quality
The electronic search found 635 articles from MEDLINE
and 987 from EMBASE. After ineligible and duplicate
papers were removed via title and abstract screening, 25
articles met the inclusion criteria, and we located a
further seven studies by screening reference lists. After a
full-text review, a total of 32 articles9,11,13,14,17–44 from 31
studies were included (see Figure 1). Since the most
recent published review,6 14 new studies have been pub-
lished that meet eligibility criteria for our review.11,14,31,33–43
The quality of the studies varied greatly (see Appendix 4);
16 studies scored b11 points, indicating high method-

corpus_questions.ground_truth: Spatial genomic data from single-cell in situ RNA profiling can be used to analyze the likelihood of colocalization within a clonal lineage by calculating p(dist(ci, cj) ≤r|i, j ∈Y ) and comparing it across different clonal populations. Similarly, such data can be utilized to examine the association between knee osteoarthritis and various occupational exposures by conducting a best evidence synthesis of studies that assess the risk of knee OA based on specific occupational activities.

corpus_questions.question: What methods were used in the study examining the association between knee OA and occupational exposure, and how does this compare to techniques mentioned in the context about spatial transcriptomics?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The study examining the association between knee OA and occupational exposure used a best evidence synthesis of studies that looked at the risk of knee OA associated with various types of occupational exposures, including heavy lifting, kneeling or knee bending, combined heavy lifting and kneeling, and stair climbing. The level of evidence for each type of occupational exposure was determined based on the design of eligible studies and their methodological quality. In contrast, the context about spatial transcriptomics discusses techniques such as single-cell in situ RNA profiling by sequential hybridization, transcriptome-scale super-resolved imaging in tissues by RNA seqFISH, and spatially resolved transcriptomics.

much work is needed to establish a comprehensive ML
platform given the versatility of MS methods and predict
relationships between genes, proteins, lipids, and metabolites
in biological pathways for target and biomarker discovery.
3.5. Mass Cytometry
Mass cytometry or cytometry by time-of-flight (CyTOF) MS is
an improved technique of flow cytometry, significantly
increasing throughput compared with traditional flow
cytometry. Briefly, CyTOF uses antibodies coupled with
heavy metal isotopes to profile more than 50 protein
biomarkers simultaneously without peak overlap in the
resulting mass spectra. Further, CyTOF is capable of profiling
large amounts of cells within a single sample. However, this
leads to challenges in analyzing large data sets with high
dimensionality. A popular analysis strategy is using manual
gating, a process in which two-dimensional plots are utilized to
visualize data and identify cell populations, traditionally by
hand or via (semi-)automated computational methods.

3.5. Mass Cytometry
Mass cytometry or cytometry by time-of-flight (CyTOF) MS is
an improved technique of flow cytometry, significantly
increasing throughput compared with traditional flow
cytometry. Briefly, CyTOF uses antibodies coupled with
heavy metal isotopes to profile more than 50 protein
biomarkers simultaneously without peak overlap in the
resulting mass spectra. Further, CyTOF is capable of profiling
large amounts of cells within a single sample. However, this
leads to challenges in analyzing large data sets with high
dimensionality. A popular analysis strategy is using manual
gating, a process in which two-dimensional plots are utilized to
visualize data and identify cell populations, traditionally by
hand or via (semi-)automated computational methods.
Unfortunately, 2-D plots are not sufficient to represent
complex high-dimensional data. Furthermore, manual gating
is time-consuming, prone to human error, and ultimately
impractical for large-scale studies, limiting throughput. As a
result, ML has been used to aid with the dimensionality
reduction of large mass-cytometry data sets for cell subset
classifications within each sample. There are plenty of

that is lower than that of the ML deviance, which can occur if the initial ﬁt was wrong due
to numerical problems, the proﬁler issues an error and stops.
Parametric bootstrapping
To avoid the asymptotic assumptions of the likelihood ratio test, at the cost of greatly in-
creased computation time, one can estimate conﬁdence intervals by parametric bootstrapping
– that is, by simulating data from the ﬁtted model, reﬁtting the model, and extracting the
new estimated parameters (or any other quantities of interest). This task is quite straightfor-
ward, since there is already a simulate method, and a refit function which re-estimates the
(RE)ML parameters for new data, starting from the previous (RE)ML estimates and re-using
the previously computed model structures (including the ﬁll-reducing permutation) for eﬃ-
ciency. The bootMer function is thus a fairly thin wrapper around a simulate/refit loop,
with a small amount of additional logic for parallel computation and error-catching. (Some
of the ideas of bootMer are adapted from merBoot (Sánchez-Espigares and Ocaña 2009), a
more ambitious framework for bootstrapping lme4 model ﬁts which unfortunately seems to
be unavailable at present.)

corpus_questions.question: What challenges arise from using mass cytometry (CyTOF) for large-scale cell analysis, and how might linear mixed models be used in addressing some analytical issues related to such high-dimensional data?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: Challenges from using mass cytometry (CyTOF) include the difficulty in analyzing large datasets with high dimensionality, often requiring manual gating or semi-automated computational methods. Linear mixed models, which can handle complex data structures and provide robust parameter estimation, could potentially address some of these analytical issues by improving the fit and reliability of model parameters.

corpus_questions.ground_truth: Parametric bootstrapping can be used to avoid the asymptotic assumptions of the likelihood ratio test in linear mixed models. This involves simulating data from the fitted model, refitting the model, and extracting new estimated parameters. In a biological research setting involving mass spectrometry, such as the studies mentioned in Context 2, researchers could apply parametric bootstrapping to validate their findings without relying on asymptotic assumptions.

corpus_questions.question: How does the integration of mass spectrometry techniques with deep learning platforms, such as SpatialData and MONAI, facilitate the preparation of datasets for deep learning applications in the context of biomarker identification?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The integration of mass spectrometry techniques with deep learning platforms like SpatialData and MONAI facilitates the preparation of datasets for deep learning applications. For instance, Context 1 provides examples of various mass spectrometry techniques used to identify biomarkers in different tissues and conditions. These techniques generate data that can be integrated into deep learning models. Context 2 demonstrates how SpatialData, which builds on a query interface, allows generating PyTorch datasets representing tiles of the original SpatialData, making it easier to prepare datasets for deep learning. Additionally, MONAI framework, mentioned in Context 2, provides specific model architectures that can be interfaced with these datasets, enabling the development of supervised cell-type prediction models.

3. Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT): CWT[6, 7] is a more sophisticated
approach that is used to split the signal into different frequency ranges. Regard-
ing the m/z scale as generalized time scale, CWT constructs a time-frequency
representation of the spectrum by mapping it from the time domain to the time-
scale domain. The essential part of CWT is the mother wavelet whose translated
and scaled versions are used to generate daughter wavelets. The mother function
we used for this evaluation is the second derivative of a gaussian function (Mex-
ican Hat Wavelet). Peak picking typically includes the inspection of multiple
scales. For peak detection (using R package msProcess) the peak candidate has
to be clearly distinguishable from the background (parameter: snr.min) and vis-
ible across at least 7 scale domains (parameter: length.min) excluding the ﬁrst
three high frequency wavelet scales (parameter: scale.min). Excluding high fre-
quency wavelets acts as ﬁlter for high frequency noise.
2.2
Reference Peaks
In order to evaluate the peak picking algorithms we deﬁned a set of reference peaks.
A peak picking algorithm can then be evaluated in terms of sensitivity (how many of
the reference peaks are found) and speciﬁcity (how many of the found peaks are part
of the reference set). An optimal algorithm has high sensitivity and high speciﬁcity.
The reference set was created in a semi-automatic process. To this end we initially

For peak detection using the Mexican Hat Wavelet in mass spectrometry data, preprocessing typically includes ensuring that the peak candidate is clearly distinguishable from the background and visible across at least 7 scale domains, excluding the first three high-frequency wavelet scales.

corpus_questions.question: What is the significance of the Mexican Hat Wavelet in the context of peak detection, and how does it relate to the concept of false positives in gene expression analysis?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The Mexican Hat Wavelet, also known as the second derivative of a Gaussian function, is crucial in peak detection as it helps in identifying peaks that are clearly distinguishable from the background and visible across multiple scale domains, thereby reducing noise. In gene expression analysis, the concept of false positives is related to the probability of incorrectly identifying a gene as significantly expressed when it is not, which is quantified by the q-value, indicating the proportion of false positives among the significant results.

volumetric data. In addition to the edge-based localization
used in the original work, we also present an intensity-based
localization approach using the Otsu threshold selection
method.
Both approaches start with the user interactively selecting
a box-shaped region of interest which bounds the fidu-
cial, using the ROIDataAquisition GUI component.
With the edge-based approach, we localize the edges in
the ROI using the Canny edge detector and then esti-
mate the optimal sphere which fits the edges using a
least-squares formulation. The notebook snippet shown in
Fig. 8 describes this formulation and its implementation
using SimpleITK and the SciPy library [14]. With the
thresholding-based approach, once the fiducial is segmented
we use SimpleITK’s LabelShapeStatisticsImage
Filter component to obtain its location as the centroid of
the segmented blob and its radius as the radius of the sphere
which has the same volume as the segmented blob.
Discussion and Conclusions
Two significant requirements associated with modern scien-
tific computational environments are that they facilitate col-
laborations and that they enable reproducibility [1, 2, 7, 21].
In this work, we presented such an environment for devel-
oping biomedical image analysis workflows using a literate

corpus_questions.question: What statistical measure is used to assess the significance of the MSH2 gene, and how does it compare to the threshold for false positives based on the Storey and Tibshirani method?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The q value, which represents the proportion of false positives among the significant genes, is used to assess the significance of the MSH2 gene. According to the Storey and Tibshirani method, the MSH2 gene has a q value of 0.013, indicating that 0.013 of the genes that are as or more extreme than MSH2 are false positives.

volumetric data. In addition to the edge-based localization
used in the original work, we also present an intensity-based
localization approach using the Otsu threshold selection

Both approaches start with the user interactively selecting
a box-shaped region of interest which bounds the fidu-
cial, using the ROIDataAquisition GUI component.
With the edge-based approach, we localize the edges in
the ROI using the Canny edge detector and then esti-
mate the optimal sphere which fits the edges using a
least-squares formulation. The notebook snippet shown in
Fig. 8 describes this formulation and its implementation
using SimpleITK and the SciPy library [14]. With the
thresholding-based approach, once the fiducial is segmented
we use SimpleITK’s LabelShapeStatisticsImage
Filter component to obtain its location as the centroid of
the segmented blob and its radius as the radius of the sphere
which has the same volume as the segmented blob.
Discussion and Conclusions
Two significant requirements associated with modern scien-
tific computational environments are that they facilitate col-
laborations and that they enable reproducibility [1, 2, 7, 21].
In this work, we presented such an environment for devel-
oping biomedical image analysis workflows using a literate
programming approach with the Python or R programming
languages. The environment allows one to provide algorith-
mic details, mathematical formulations, figures, and imple-

Single cell imaging has drawn great attentions recently. As an
untargeted, label-free method with high sensitivity and
chemical speciﬁcity as well as dynamic range, HR-MSI presents
a great advantage and becomes a potential platform for
multicomponent imaging in single cells. MSI has been
successful at imaging lipids with subcellular lateral resolu-
tion.19,33,49,61,163,164 Further development is needed to open
the ﬁeld of single cell MSI to new possibilities, such as
subcellular imaging of carbohydrates, nucleic acids, proteins,
metabolites, and pharmaceuticals. As the sampling probe has
been signiﬁcantly smaller than the size of individual cell and
reached sub-100 nm, organelle chemical imaging (see Figure
4) will become possible not long in the future.
■CONCLUSION
Incredible advances in both technology and methodology have
signiﬁcantly improved the spatial resolution for HR-MSI,
which provides fresh impetus to the entire MSI ﬁeld. The
emergence of admirable approaches, such as modifying the
laser optics, utilizing diﬀerent geometries of the source,
applying EUV or VUV laser, and near-ﬁeld techniques, has
already allowed submicrometer resolution imaging. As such a
level of spatial resolution is a new frontier, some challenges
including the corresponding limited sensitivity and mass
resolution appear subsequently. The introduction of laser
postionization and new mass analyzers with superior mass
resolution, signiﬁcantly improving sensitivity and the ability to

corpus_questions.question: How does the edge-based localization approach in volumetric data differ from the intensity-based approach using threshold selection, and what advantages might these methods offer in single cell imaging with high-resolution mass spectrometry imaging (HR-MSI)?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The edge-based localization approach starts by localizing the edges in the region of interest (ROI) using the Canny edge detector and then estimating the optimal sphere which fits the edges using a least-squares formulation. On the other hand, the intensity-based approach uses the Otsu threshold selection method to segment the fiducial and then calculates its location as the centroid of the segmented blob and its radius as the radius of the sphere which has the same volume as the segmented blob. These methods could offer precise localization and segmentation capabilities, which are crucial for the subcellular imaging of various components in single cells using HR-MSI.

corpus_questions.question: How can ANOVA procedures be applied in the context of single-cell imaging, and what additional information is required to estimate the components of variance in MS/MS runs?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: ANOVA procedures can be used to estimate the components of variance in single-cell imaging when random measurement variation is generally assumed to be Gaussian. To estimate these components, additional information such as the observed analyte Yij and its mathematical representation as Yij = m1ai1eij is required. Furthermore, in the context of MS/MS runs, the identification of proteins and the calculation of the expected amount of cellular DNA using the human genome size and base pair mass are necessary to estimate the protein mass per cell.

MS/MS runs. In triplicate analyses, MaxQuant identified about
7000 proteins in each of the cell lines (supplemental Table S1).
The human genome contains around 3.2  109 base pairs
(28). Multiplying this number by the average mass of a base
pair (615.9 Da) and by the ploidy of the respective cell type
yields an expected amount of cellular DNA. We used a value
of 6.5 pg for a diploid human cell to calculate cell numbers.
Dividing the total amount of protein input by these cell num-
bers, we obtained a protein mass per cell that was very similar
to that obtained by dividing the total protein input amount by
the counted cell numbers (supplemental Table S2).
Histones Serve as a “Proteomic Ruler” for Absolute Scaling
of Proteomic Data—In eukaryotic cells, DNA is packaged in
chromatin by histones, and the mass of the DNA is about
equal to the combined mass of histones (29). We therefore
wondered whether the summed intensity of histones in a
deep, eukaryotic proteome could serve as a proxy for the
amount of DNA and therefore for the cell number. There are
five major histone types, which are expressed in many iso-
forms and variants that are relevant for many aspects of
chromatin biology. For our approach, however, we employed
the summed MS signal of all histone-derived peptides, irre-
spective of which histone they mapped to or how they were
assembled in protein groups. This value reflects the cumula-
tive histone mass. In this way, we used the MS signal of an

corpus_questions.question: How does the identification of proteins in cell lines help in estimating the cell numbers, and what statistical model is used for cell type decomposition in single-cell transcriptomics?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: MaxQuant identified about 7000 proteins in each of the cell lines, and by dividing the total amount of protein input by the calculated cell numbers, a protein mass per cell can be obtained. For cell type decomposition in single-cell transcriptomics, RCTD (Robust Cell Type Decomposition) is used, which explains gene counts in each spot as a mixture of cell type contributions, unobserved platform effects, and spot-specific mRNA sampling effects.

MS/MS runs. In triplicate analyses, MaxQuant identified about
7000 proteins in each of the cell lines (supplemental Table S1).
The human genome contains around 3.2  109 base pairs
(28). Multiplying this number by the average mass of a base
pair (615.9 Da) and by the ploidy of the respective cell type
yields an expected amount of cellular DNA. We used a value
of 6.5 pg for a diploid human cell to calculate cell numbers.
Dividing the total amount of protein input by these cell num-
bers, we obtained a protein mass per cell that was very similar
to that obtained by dividing the total protein input amount by
the counted cell numbers (supplemental Table S2).
Histones Serve as a “Proteomic Ruler” for Absolute Scaling
of Proteomic Data—In eukaryotic cells, DNA is packaged in
chromatin by histones, and the mass of the DNA is about
equal to the combined mass of histones (29). We therefore
wondered whether the summed intensity of histones in a
deep, eukaryotic proteome could serve as a proxy for the
amount of DNA and therefore for the cell number. There are
five major histone types, which are expressed in many iso-
forms and variants that are relevant for many aspects of
chromatin biology. For our approach, however, we employed
the summed MS signal of all histone-derived peptides, irre-
spective of which histone they mapped to or how they were
assembled in protein groups. This value reflects the cumula-
tive histone mass. In this way, we used the MS signal of an

proportions [91]. This was followed by robust cell type 
decomposition (RCTD), which used a different statisti-
cal model to explain gene counts in each spot as a mix-
ture of cell type contributions, unobserved platform—e.g. 
single-cell or spatial transcriptomics—effects, and spot-
specific mRNA sampling effects, allowing it confidently 
assign cell types to spots much more frequently than in 
NMFreg (86.9% of spots vs 24.8%) [92]. Because of the 
similar data structures between Slide-seqV2 and Visium 
data, these methods are also applicable to the latter. 
Alternatives include stereoscope, cell2location, Tangram, 
and destVI [93–96]. stereoscope, like RCTD, models the 
composition of each spot’s transcriptome as a mixture of 
transcripts from different cells with additional platform-
specific effects. Cell2location and destVI are both con-
tained within the scVI analysis framework and use deep 
learning approaches to achieve relatively high speed, as 
does Tangram. destVI is unique in that compared to the 
other tools discussed, which deconvolute spatial data 
from a reference of discrete cell types, it maps continu-
ous cell types. In effect, this allows it to map not only a 
known reference cell type but also variation within that 
cell type. Tangram also incorporates imaging data such 
as H&E staining during its deep learning process to first 
segment cells in the image and to use this as the basis 
for the number of cells inferred through deconvolution.

corpus_questions.question: How does the summed intensity of histones in a deep, eukaryotic proteome potentially serve as a proxy, and what statistical method is mentioned in another context that can be applied to similar data structures for cell type decomposition?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The summed intensity of histones in a deep, eukaryotic proteome can serve as a proxy for absolute scaling of proteomic data because the mass of DNA is about equal to the combined mass of histones. Additionally, RCTD (Robust Proportions) is mentioned as a statistical method that can be applied to similar data structures for cell type decomposition.

corpus_questions.question: How does the statistical model used in RCTD differ from the methods used in lipid analysis, and what kind of data structures do Slide-seqV2 and Visium share that make RCTD applicable to both?
corpus_questions.ground_truth: The statistical model used in RCTD explains gene counts in each spot as a mixture of cell type contributions, unobserved platform effects, and spot-specific mRNA sampling effects. In contrast, lipid analysis involves the relative quantification of specific lipids between islet and exocrine tissues, where significant differences in lipid abundance were observed. Slide-seqV2 and Visium share similar data structures, making RCTD applicable to both.

interpretability. For each protein and each pairwise comparison,

ground proteins. (Fig. 4B). Shotgun proteomics identified nearly
